text: You can use locals() to get a dict of the local variables in your function, like this:

code:
def foo(a, b, c):
    print locals()

>>> foo(1, 2, 3)
{'a': 1, 'c': 3, 'b': 2}

text: This is a bit hackish, however, as locals() returns all variables in the local scope, not only the arguments passed to the function, so if you don't call it at the very top of the function the result might contain more information than you want:

code:
def foo(a, b, c):
    x = 4
    y = 5
    print locals()

>>> foo(1, 2, 3)
{'y': 5, 'x': 4, 'c': 3, 'b': 2, 'a': 1}
